close_symbols: OS_SUCCESS (macro / enumerator for success return value)
explanation: To determine whether OS_remove violates the MISRA rule on well-formed for loops we must inspect any for loops in the function itself and in any functions it calls (because the rule considers the behavior of functions called within a for loop body). The target function directly calls OS_TranslatePath and OS_FileRemove_Impl, so their full definitions are required. OS_remove also references OS_MAX_LOCAL_PATH_LEN, OS_SUCCESS and the type int32 (to interpret buffer sizing and return-value semantics), so those symbols are needed. OS_TranslatePath (per the static graph) calls OS_strnlen, OS_ObjectIdGetBySearch, OS_ObjectIndexFromToken, OS_ObjectIdRelease and OS_printf; each of those implementations must be examined for for-loops or side effects that could affect loop counters when they are called from a for loop context. Finally, OS_TranslatePath and the target function reference UT stub helpers in the graph (UT_Stub_RegisterReturnType, UT_Stub_RegisterContextWithMetaData, UT_ExecuteBasicHandler, UT_Stub_GetReturnValuePtr) which can alter control flow in test/build configurations; their definitions should be checked to ensure they do not introduce for-loops or side effects that would cause a violation. Inspecting these symbols allows a complete assessment of any for-loops (their initialization, condition, increment clauses, loop counters, and modifications inside the body or called functions) relevant to MISRA's requirements.
